questions.text: Which of the following inserts into the talus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above None of the given muscles inserts into the talus

Highyeild:

FRACTURES OF THE TALUS Minor fractures in the form of a small chip from the margins of one of the articular surfaces of the talus are more common than the more serious fracture i.e. fracture of the neck of the talus. RELEVANT ANATOMY Blood supply to the talus: This is the only bone of the foot without any muscle attachment. The main blood supply to the talus is from the anastomotic ring of blood vessels, the osseous vessels entering its neck and running postero-laterally within the bone to supply its body. Therefore, blood supply to the body of the talus is often cut off following fractures occurring through the neck. MECHANISM Fracture of the neck of the talus results from forced dorsiflexion of the ankle (Fig-21.16). Typically, this injury is sustained in an aircraft crash where the rudder bar is driven forcibly against the middle of the sole of the foot (Aviator's fracture), resulting in forced dorsiflexion of the ankle; the neck, being a weak area, gives way. This may be associated with dislocation of the body of the talus backwards, out of the ankle-mortise. Vascularity of the body of the talus may be compromised. Mechanism of injury of fracture neck of the talus DIAGNOSIS Unless carefully examined on a lateral X-ray of the ankle, this fracture is frequently missed because of the overlapping of the tarsal bones. TREATMENT It depends upon the displacement. If undisplaced, a below-knee plaster cast for 8-10 weeks is sufficient. In a displaced fracture, open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture with a screw is required. COMPLICATIONS Avascular necrosis and non-union: Because of the poor blood supply, after a fracture through the neck, the body of the talus becomes avascular. The avascular fragment fails to unite with rest of the bone and gradually collapses, leading to deformation of the bone, and eventually osteoarthritis of the ankle. Osteoarthritis: Besides avascular necrosis of the talus, an associated injury to its articular cartilage may lead to osteoarthritis of the ankle. The patient complains of pain and stiffness. Treatment is mostly by physiotherapy and fomentation. In severe cases, an ankle arthrodesis may be needed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Tibialis anterior inserts on the medial cuneiform and base of 1st Metatarsal bone of foot Option: B. Tibialis posterior inserts on the tuberosity of navicular bone, all cuneiform bone, cuboid bone, bases of 2-4 Metatarsal bone Option: C. Extensor digitorum longus inserts on distal and middle phalanges of digits 2-5

questions.text: A 21-year-old rugby player sustained a contact knee injury while being tackled. On clinical examination, he has a near-normal Lachman and McMurray test. Sag sign, Posterior drawer test, Dial test, and varus stress tests are normal. He has pain and a 4 -5mm opening on the valgus stress test at 20-30 degrees of flexion. Which structure is injured in this player?

options.label: B
options.text: Medial Meniscus and Anterior Cruciate Ligament

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral Meniscus and Lateral Collateral Ligament

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superficial Medial Collateral Ligament The clinical presentation is consistent with an injury to the superficial medial/tibial collateral ligament (MCL) of the knee. It provides main stability to valgus stress at all angles.

Highyeild:

Collateral injury The two collateral ligaments provide stability to the knee from medial and lateral side as medial collateral and lateral collateral ligaments. These can be tested by varus and valgus stress tests. Collateral ligament injury The medial structures medial (tibial) collateral ligament (MCL) and medial capsular ligament are first to fail, followed by ACL tear. Examination table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} Direction of Force Position of knee Ligament Tested Varus/Valgus Full extension PCL, Posterior capsule Varus Valgus 30° flexion LCL MCL Posterior 90° flexion PCL Anterior - 30° flexion (lachman's test) - 90° flexion (anterior drawer) ACL Essential features of knee ligament injury table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} Name of the ligament Mechanism, of injury Clinical features Pain Swelling Tenderness Tests Medial collateral Valgus force Medial side Medial side Medially, on the femoral condyle Valgus stress + at 30° knee flexion Lateral collateral Varus Lateral side Lateral side Laterally, on fibular head Varus stress + at 30° knee flexion Anterior cruciate Twisting extension Diffuse Haemarthrosis Vague Anterior drawer test+ Lachmann test + Posterior cruciate Backward force on tibia Diffuse Haemarthrosis Vague Posterior drawer test+ ANKLE LIGAMENT INJURIES One of the most stable joints. Basic anatomy: table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} Medial Collateral/ deltoid lig. Lateral Collateral Ligament Fibrous capsule ↓ ● Tibiotalar lig. ● Tibiocalcaneal lig. ● Tibionavicular lig ↓ ● Talofibular lig. ↳ Ant. ↳ Post. ● Calcaneofibular lig. ↓ Absent from: ● Ant. Inferior part Post. Superior part Plantar CalcaneoNavicular ligament (Spring ligament) → Medial arch support of foot

questions.text: Which of the following method is best to treat a comminuted fracture of the distal pole of the patella?

options.label: B
options.text: Wiring and attachment of the fragments and pop again

options.label: C
options.text: Excision of the fragments and reattachment of the ligament to the proximal fragment

questions.correct_answer: C. Excision of the fragments and reattachment of the ligament to the proximal fragment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Excision of the fragments and reattachment of the ligament to the proximal fragment In comminuted fractures with displacement, it is difficult to restore a perfectly smooth articular surface, so excision of the patella (patellectomy) is the preferred option, followed by reattachment of the ligament to the proximal fragment.

Highyeild:

Comminuted fracture: In comminuted fractures with displacement, it is difficult to restore a perfectly smooth articular surface, so excision of the patella (patellectomy) is the preferred option. This takes care of any future risk of osteoarthritis at the patello- femoral joint. With improvement in fixation techniques, more and more comminuted fractures of the patella are being reconstructed (patella saving operations). Comminuted fracture: In comminuted fractures with displacement, it is difficult to restore a perfectly smooth articular surface, so excision of the patella (patellectomy) is the preferred option.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Since only the distal fragment is comminuted , the best treatment would be partial patellectomy followed by reattachment of the patellar tendon. Option: B. Difficult to reduce comminuted fracture Option: D. Not the preferred treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male came with a history of road traffic accidents. He is suspected to have a pelvic injury. All are the following statements true except?

options.label: A
options.text: On clinical examination, the straight leg raising test is the most commonly used screening test for pelvic fractures

options.label: B
options.text: In case of suspected pelvic injuries, special X-rays - outlet and inlet views are taken

options.label: C
options.text: X-rays should be taken following the removal of the pelvic binder only

options.label: D
options.text: CT pelvis with 3D reconstruction is the best investigation to detect pelvic fractures

questions.correct_answer: A. On clinical examination, the straight leg raising test is the most commonly used screening test for pelvic fractures
questions.explanation:
Solution:

On clinical examination, the straight leg raising test is the most commonly used screening test for pelvic fractures On clinical examination, the straight leg raising test is the most commonly used screening test for pelvic fractures is incorrect

Highyeild:

The pelvic compression test is a useful screening test in all such cases. Pelvic compression test: The patient lies supine on the couch. The examiner compresses both iliac crests of the patient's pelvis towards each other. Any pain during this maneuver or a ‘springy’ feeling, is an indicator of pelvic fracture. A pelvic distraction test may reveal similar findings. A CT scan may be needed for better evaluation in cases where operative intervention is contemplated. An X-Ray should be taken following the removal of the pelvic binder to ensure no displacement of the pelvis and falsely reduce the pelvic fracture in X-Ray.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Correct statement. Option: C. Correct statement. Option: D. Correct statement.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy developed pain over the medial aspect of his right knee that gradually increased after a mild slip and fall while he was playing. On palpation, a painful, palpable medial parapatellar cord is felt with snapping sensations on movements. All the statements are true of this condition except-

options.label: A
options.text: These symptoms are due to synovial septations remnants that get inflamed

options.label: C
options.text: Most common location is the infrapatellar region

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment is Incision and drainage of the lesion

questions.correct_answer: D. Treatment is Incision and drainage of the lesion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Treatment is Incision and drainage of the lesion Option: D. Treatment is initially conservative and definitive treatment is excision .

Highyeild:

Plica syndrome Plica syndrome of the knee is a constellation of signs and symptoms that occur secondary to injury or overuse. An otherwise normal structure, a plica can be a significant source of anterior knee pain. The etiology of symptomatic plica is unclear. Potential causes of inflammation include repetitive stress, a single blunt trauma, loose bodies, osteochondritis dissecans, meniscal tears, or other aggravating knee pathology. The most common symptomatic plica is medial plica; occasionally, suprapatellar plica may also be symptomatic. Most common are infrapatellar plica Presentation This may be referred to as a positive TARP sign, in which TARP stands for the following: T-Taut A- Articular band R- Reproduces P- Pain Treatment The most common symptomatic plica is medial parapatellar plica. Surgical intervention for plica syndrome should be considered when symptoms have persisted and efforts at nonoperative management have failed for a period typically approaching 6 months. Permanent modification of athletic activity is usually another option, but patients rarely find this acceptable.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. This condition is plica syndrome . Plica is synovial septation remnants . The most common location is infrapatellar but the most common symptomatic location is the medial plica. Above is the correct statement. Option: B. Correct statement. Option: C. - Correct statement.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male child comes with pain and effusion over the superolateral aspect of the knee. He complains of occasional knee locking for the last 2 years gradually progressive. Wilson’s test was found to be positive on examination. All the following statements are true about this condition except-

options.label: A
options.text: Most common cause of loose body in the young

options.label: B
options.text: Special X-ray view, the intercondylar –Tunnel view is taken in this condition

options.label: C
options.text: CT is the definitive investigation for this condition

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment includes Microdrilling or microfractures created

questions.correct_answer: C. CT is the definitive investigation for this condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT is the definitive investigation for this condition Option: C. Definitive investigation is MRI and Not CT.

Highyeild:

Osteochondritis dissecans It leads to softening & separation of a portion of the joint surface; resulting in development of a small segment of necrotic bone in the joint. Knee is the most commonly affected joint.; with > 80% of lesions occurring on the lateral part of medial femoral condyle (exactly where the patella makes contact in full flexion). Clinical features 15-20 years male, presents with intermittent ache & swelling, localized tenderness & Wilson's sign (i.e. pain is felt in straightening the flexed knee in medial rotation, put not in lateral rotation) The best X-ray view is intercondylar (tunnel view). MRI can make an early diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. This condition is Osteochondritis The most common location is the lateral aspect Option: B. Special X-ray view, the intercondylar –Tunnel view is taken in this condition.Correct statement. Option: D. Treatment depends on stable or unstable lesions. Stable lesions are treated conservatively with protected weight bearing while unstable lesions require surgery – microdrilling/microfractures or fixation with k wires or screws.

questions.text: What is the measurement shown in the figure below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Insall Salvati Index Option: B. Insall – Salvati index – Ratio between the length of patellar ligament to the length of the patella. It is used in differentiating patella alta and baja. Normal value – 0.8 to 1.2 Less than 0.8-patella baja Greater than 1.2 – patella alta

Highyeild:

Patella Alta (High riding patella) The position of patella is considered high. Can be idiopathic or secondary to a patellar tendon rupture. It is associations with idiopathic retro-patellar pain, recurrent dislocation of the patella, chondromalacia patellae, knee joint effusion Blumensaat line is a line drawn through the roof of the intercondylar notch, the lower pole of the patella is supposed to touch this line if it is above this line then it is termed as patella alta and thus predisposed to lateral dislocation HYP Insall Salvati ratio is PTL / PL (as shown in fig) or LT / LP. Normal is 0.8 to 1.2. If it is more than 1.2 is called high riding patella alta. Less than 0.8 is patella baja (Patella infra) In question they have reversed this Insall Salvati ratio.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Blumensaat line – line along the roof the intercondylar notch at 30 degrees of knee flexion normally touches the lower pole of patella. Option: C. Blackburne Peel index-another index used in recurrent patellar dislocation Option: D. Above shown is not congruence angle.

questions.text: A 15 year old girl athlete developed pain over the knee aggravated by activity. She gives a history of not being able to sit in the class with the knees flexed for long durations. This girl is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome Option: D. D- The girl is suffering from Patellofemoral pain syndrome/Chondromalacia patella

Highyeild:

Chondromalacia of the patella occurs in adolescents and young adults. The condition is more common in females. It can be related to the abnormal position of the knee. Symptoms: A grating or grinding sensation when the knee is flexed Knee pain in the front of the knee that occurs when you get up after sitting for a long period of time Knee pain that worsens when you use stairs or get out of a chair Knee tenderness Treatment Temporarily resting the knee and taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) Stretch the muscles on the back (hamstrings) and front (quadriceps) of upper leg. Avoid running straight down hills; walk down instead. Bicycle or swim, instead of running. Reduce the amount of exercise you do. Run on a smooth, soft surface such as a track, rather than on cement. Other techniques are: Special shoe inserts and support devices (orthotics) may help people with flat feet. Taping to realign the knee cap may help prevent symptoms. It is seen in young adult females usually complaining of anterior knee pain. Here there is softening and fibrillation of the articular surface of the patella. Characteristically patient presents with a history of not being able to sit for long durations (Theatre sign positive). The girl is suffering from Patellofemoral pain syndrome/Chondromalacia patella It is seen in young adult females usually complaining of anterior knee pain. Here there is softening and fibrillation of the articular surface of the patella. Characteristically patient presents with a history of not being able to sit for long durations (Theatre sign positive). Synovial Chondromatosis – develops anterior knee pain with multiple loose bodies in the joint (snowstorm knee). Diagnosed with x rays Plica syndrome – knee pain mostly over the medial aspect of the knee with thickened band felt on palpation. Osgood – Schlatter disease – presents with pain and swelling over the tibial tubercle.\

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Synovial Chondromatosis – develops anterior knee pain with multiple loose bodies in the joint (snowstorm knee). Diagnosed with x ray Option: B. Plica syndrome – knee pain mostly over the medial aspect of the knee with thickened band felt on palpation. Option: C. Osgood – Schlatter disease – presents with pain and swelling over the tibial tubercle

questions.text: A 12 year old male child came to the clinic with bilateral genu valgum. The Q-angle was measured in the boy. All these conditions present with an increased Q-angle except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Internal tibial torsion Option: C. Internal tibial torsion does not present with an increased Q-angle.

Highyeild:

Q-Angle It is formed by the line of pull of the quadriceps mechanism and that of the patellar tendon as they intersect at the center of the patella. This angle is represented by the intersection of a line drawn from the anterior superior iliac spine to the center of the patella with a second line drawn from the center of the tibial tuberosity to the center of the patella. For accurate measurement, the patella is centered on the trochlea by flexing the knee 30 degrees. Normal angle in males 8 to 10 degrees; in females, the normal angle is 15 degrees ± 5 degrees. The factors that can increase this Q angle are genu valgum, increased femoral anteversion, external tibial torsion, a laterally positioned tibial tuberosity, and a tight lateral retinaculum. The factors that increase the Q angle can be a contributing factor in recurrent patellar dislocation Q-angle is the angle formed between the lines joining the ASIS to centre of patella and ano ther line from centre of patella to tibial tubercle. It is increased in genu valgum, femoral anteversion and external tibial torsion. Normal value – 8-10 degrees in males 10- 17 degrees in females

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Q-angle is the angle formed between the lines joining the ASIS to the center of patella and another line from center of patella to tibial tubercle Femoral anteversion presents with an increased Q-angle. Option: B. External tibial torsion presents with an increased Q-angle Option: D. Genu valgum presents with an increased Q-angle

questions.text: This test is positive in all the following conditions except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inferior gluteal nerve palsy Option: D. - Gluteus medius and minimus are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. So in Inferior gluteal nerve palsy,test will be negative Trendelenburg test is done to assess the abductor mechanism of the hip. Gluteus medius and minimus are supplied by superior gluteal nerve. This test is positive in - (a) No fulcrum – eg. Hip dislocation, destruction of hip (b) Ineffective lever arm – eg. Neck of femur fracture (c) Ineffective contraction of abductor muscles. Eg. Weakness of abductor muscles like in polio, coxa vara due to short lever arm.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Trendelenburg test is done to assess the abductor mechanism of the hip and it is positive in coxa vara. Option: B. Test is positive in Hip dislocation. Option: C. Test is positive in Gluteus medius

Solution:

Pott's fracture Option: A. Bimalleolar fra cture is also called Pott's fracture

Highyeild:

Definition- A Pott's fracture is a type of ankle fracture that is characterized by a break in one or more bony prominences on the sides of the ankle known as the malleoli. Also known as Broken Ankle, Ankle Fracture and malleolar fracture. Pott's fracture often occurs in combination with other injuries such as a sprained ankle or other fractures of the foot, ankle or lower leg.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Not Massonaives fracture Option: C. Not Chopart's fracture Option: D. Not Jone's fracture
